papers.abstract: This essay details the development and current NEH-funded research goals of The Media Ecology Project (MEP), directed by Prof. Mark Williams and designed by Dr. John Bell at Dartmouth. The virtuous cycle of access, research, and preservation that MEP realizes is built upon a foundation of technological advance (software development) plus large-scale partnership networks with scholars, students, and institutions of historical memory such as moving image archives. The development of our Onomy vocabulary tool and NEH-funded Semantic Annotation Tool (SAT) are detailed, including their application in two advancement grants from the NEH regarding 1) early cinema history, and 2) television newsfilm that covered the civil rights movement in the U.S. MEP is fundamentally 1) a sustainability project that 2) develops literacies of moving image and visual culture history, and 3) functions as a collaborative incubator that fosters new research questions and methods ranging from traditional Arts and Humanities close-textual analysis to computational distant reading. New research questions in relation to these workflows will literally transform the value of media archives and support the development of interdisciplinary research and pedagogy/curricular goals (e.g., media literacy) regarding the study of visual culture history and its legacies in the 21st century.

events.Text: This essay details the development and current NEH-funded research goals of The Media Ecology Project (MEP), directed by Prof. Mark Williams and designed by Dr. John Bell at Dartmouth. The virtuous cycle of access, research, and preservation that MEP realizes is built upon a foundation of technological advance (software development) plus large-scale partnership networks with scholars, students, and institutions of historical memory such as moving image archives.

The development of our Onomy vocabulary tool and NEH-funded Semantic Annotation Tool (SAT) are detailed, including their application in two advancement grants from the NEH regarding 1) early cinema history, and 2) television newsfilm that covered the civil rights movement in the U.S. MEP is fundamentally 1) a sustainability project that 2) develops literacies of moving image and visual culture history, and 3) functions as a collaborative incubator that fosters new research questions and methods ranging from traditional Arts and Humanities close-textual analysis to computational distant reading.

Agent: Our Onomy vocabulary tool and NEH-funded Semantic Annotation Tool (SAT)

Secondary Object: to address fundamental issues in representing, preserving, and studying visual cultural heritage and promote digital literacy in examining historic material across disciplines

Context: NEH grants support research activities in two advancement grants addressing topics such as early cinema history and television newsfilm coverage of the civil rights movement in the U.S.
MEP serves as a sustainability project focused on moving image history
Purpose: To advance understanding of cultural heritage preservation and promote digital literacy among students studying historic materials across disciplines.
Method: Both traditional Arts and Humanities close-textual analysis and computational distant reading are utilized.
Results: Outcomes include effective utilization of the tools in advancing research objectives.
Analysis: Interpretations explain the effectiveness of combining traditional and computational methods in enhancing analytical capabilities.
Challenge: Potential difficulties lie in integrating diverse methodologies cohesively and maintaining precision across varied data sources.
Ethical: Concerns center around inclusive representation of marginalized voices and ensuring equitable access to technology despite varying levels of resource availability.
Implications: Long-term benefits include improved educational opportunities and fostering expanded interdisciplinary collaborations driven by innovative research tools.

events.Text: New research questions in relation to these workflows will literally transform the value of media archives and support the development of interdisciplinary research and pedagogy/curricular goals (e.g., media literacy) regarding the study of visual culture history and its legacies in the 21st century.

Purpose: developing interdisciplinary research and pedagogy/curricular goals regarding the study of visual culture history and its legacies in the 21st century
Results: transform the value of media archives
Analysis: support the development of interdisciplinary research and pedagogy/curricular goals
Implications: potentially influence the advancement of visual culture history and its legacy considerations in the 21st century through enhanced media archive value

papers.abstract: This paper examines musical artificial intelligence (AI) algorithms that can not only learn from big data, but learn in ways that would be familiar to a musician or music theorist. This paper aims to find more effective links between music-related big data and artificial intelligence algorithms by incorporating principles with a strong grounding in music theory. We show that it is possible to increase the accuracy of two common algorithms (mode prediction and key prediction) by using music-theory-based techniques during the data preparation process. We offer methods to alter often-used Krumhansl Kessler profiles [Krumhansl and Kessler 1982], and the manner in which they are employed during preprocessing, to aid the connection of musical big data and mode or key predicting algorithms.

events.Text: This paper examines musical artificial intelligence (AI) algorithms that can not only learn from big data, but learn in ways that would be familiar to a musician or music theorist. This paper aims to find more effective links between music-related big data and artificial intelligence algorithms by incorporating principles with a strong grounding in music theory.

Primary Object: AI algorithms that can learn from big data
principles with a strong grounding in music theory

Context: incorporate principles with a strong grounding in music theory
Purpose: find more effective links between music-related big data and artificial intelligence algorithms
Method: analyze large datasets and apply AI models influenced by music theory
Analysis: established relationships between music data and AI capabilities guided by music theory
Challenge: challenges associated with handling complex patterns in music data affecting AI performance
Ethical: no explicit mentions of ethical concerns regarding AI integration with music
Implications: paves the way for future advancements in merging AI with music education and creation
Contradictions: no direct contradictions noted with existing knowledge
